Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Influence of Blame Mitigation and Guilt Induction on True Versus False Confessions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
False confessions account for approximately 30% of the more than 325 wrongful convictions identified by The Innocence Project. Interrogation themes, which attempt to rationalize and minimize the seriousness of the crime or project blame away from the suspect, have been shown to increase the likelihood of false confessions. It is possible that these blame mitigation strategies may also inhibit confessions from guilty suspects, given that true confessions are related to feelings of guilt and blame mitigation approaches are designed to reduce feelings of guilt. This project will examine blame mitigation in an interrogation as well as a novel interrogation technique (guilt induction) in which an interrogator emphasizes a suspect's responsibility for the crime, the impact his or her actions had on the victim, and how the suspect's behavior failed to meet an ideal standard.

Experiments conducted here will (1) test practitioners' beliefs that blame mitigation techniques do not produce false confessions, and (2) assess whether guilt induction leads guilty, but not innocent, suspects to confess. The experiments will also assess how these techniques affect suspects' perceptions of responsibility and future punishment. This project will use experimental methods. Participants will imagine themselves in an interrogation (Experiment 1) or experience an interrogation in a laboratory paradigm (Experiment 2) that includes blame mitigation, guilt induction, or direct questioning interrogation techniques.

This project has the potential to benefit society by developing an empirically-based perspective on what works in the interrogation room. Given the prevalence of false confessions in our criminal justice system and current debates over the use of coercive interrogation methods, it is critical that we develop more diagnostic, evidence-based interrogation approaches. This project will also provide an important test of contrasting theories of confession proposed by practitioners and researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project evaluated two interrogation techniques: blame mitigation, where the interrogator conveys the message that the suspect is not at fault for what happened, and guilt induction, where the interrogator seeks to make the suspect feel guilty for the crime. There were two aims to this project. First, we tested interrogation practitioners’ assumptions that blame mitigation interrogation techniques can reduce a suspect’s perceptions of his or her moral responsibility for a transgression without also affecting perceptions of legal responsibility (i.e., punishment). Second, we assessed whether guilt induction interrogation techniques led to a higher ratio of true-to-false confessions. We also evaluated the psychological processes that produce true and false confessions. With regards to the first aim, we found that blame mitigation techniques lowered mock suspects’ expectations of the punishment they would receive upon confessing. However, blame mitigation techniques did not affect suspects’ perceptions of their responsibility. With regards to the second aim, we found that blame mitigation and guilt induction techniques produced comparable levels of false confessions, and comparable levels of true confessions. We also found that people are more likely to falsely confess when they perceive greater pressure from the interrogator to confess, and that people are more likely to truthfully confess when they feel guilty for the transgression, when they expect lesser punishment upon confessing, and when they perceive greater pressure from the interrogator to confess.

 

This project’s intellectual merit was to test fundamental hypotheses regarding blame mitigation and guilt induction in the interrogation room. Interrogators assert that they should minimize suspects’ feelings of guilt with blame mitigation approaches. However, research has recently demonstrated that people are more likely to truthfully confess when they feel guilty, suggesting that guilt induction may be a more effective interrogation approach. Although there were no differences between the blame mitigation and guilt induction interrogation techniques in the current research, people were still more likely to truthfully confess when they felt guilty. These findings suggest that guilt induction may still be a viable alternative to current practices (i.e., blame mitigation) if the guilt induction technique were improved.

 

This project’s intellectual merit was to also evaluate the psychological factors that contribute to true and false confessions. This project furthered our understanding of why guilty and innocent suspects confess, and the results could be used to improve interrogation techniques in the future. For example, the guilt induction technique, contrary to our hypothesis, actually led to false confessions because it increased suspects’ perceptions of the pressure to confess. The knowledge that guilt induction led to increased perceptions of pressure to confess, which in turn led to more false confessions, could lead to an important intervention: false confessions may be reduced if there is less pressure from the interrogator to confess.

 

This project’s broader impact was to disseminate research findings to interrogation practitioners. However, the results indicated that the technique we sought to develop was not an effective alternative to blame mitigation. The researchers plan to continue this line of research in the future to improve the guilt induction technique. If the guilt induction technique works effectively, the results will be disseminated to practitioners at that time.

 

Additionally, this project had broader impact via mentorship of a female doctoral student and undergraduate research assistants, many of whom were Hispanic/Latino. The female doctoral student completed her doctoral dissertation as part of this project and has since been employed as a postdoctoral researcher. Additionally, several of the undergraduate research assistants have been accepted to graduate school and law school, and several other research assistants plan to apply in the future. Assisting with the project gave these students experience conducting research and enhanced the likelihood that they would pursue advanced degrees.
